<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 348, 293]]<|/det|>
## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
0606/13  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 154, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2020  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 326, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 228, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 880, 604]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 219, 649]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 650, 728, 682]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[398, 73, 599, 89]]<|/det|>
Mathematical Formulae  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 136, 554, 154]]<|/det|>
## 1. ALGEBRA  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 168, 242, 185]]<|/det|>
Quadratic Equation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 197, 368, 215]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(a x^{2} + b x + c = 0\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 215, 576, 250]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2} - 4ac}}{2a}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 266, 230, 282]]<|/det|>
Binomial Theorem  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 285, 737, 325]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^{n} = a^{n} + \binom{n}{1} a^{n - 1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n - 2}b^{2} + \ldots +\binom{n}{r} a^{n - r}b^{r} + \ldots +b^{n}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 330, 477, 370]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n - r)!r!}\)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 393, 384, 410]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series \(u_{n} = a + (n - 1)d\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[255, 413, 522, 442]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{1}{2} n(a + l) = \frac{1}{2} n\{2a + (n - 1)d\}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 466, 270, 483]]<|/det|>
Geometric series \(u_{n} = a r^{n - 1}\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[255, 486, 416, 520]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{a(1 - r^{n})}{1 - r} (r\neq 1)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[255, 523, 406, 552]]<|/det|>
\[S_{\infty} = \frac{a}{1 - r} (|r|< 1)\]  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[401, 574, 586, 591]]<|/det|>
## 2. TRIGONOMETRY  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 605, 161, 621]]<|/det|>
Identities  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[425, 621, 574, 670]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^{2}A + \cos^{2}A = 1\] \[\sec^{2}A = 1 + \tan^{2}A\] \[\csc^{2}A = 1 + \cot^{2}A\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 700, 243, 716]]<|/det|>
Formulae for \(\Delta ABC\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 717, 578, 750]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 758, 584, 777]]<|/det|>
\[a^{2} = b^{2} + c^{2} - 2bc\cos A\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 785, 551, 813]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta = \frac{1}{2} bc\sin A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 99, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 384, 920, 425]]<|/det|>

Using your values of \(A\) and \(b\), find

the value of \(y\) when \(x = 2\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 536, 920, 555]]<|/det|>

In this question all lengths are in centimetres.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 300, 920, 336]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the figure \(ABC\). The arc \(AB\) is part of a circle, centre \(O\), radius \(r\), and is of length \(1.45r\). The point \(O\) lies on the straight line \(CB\) such that \(CO = 0.5r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 348, 144, 365]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 348, 410, 365]]<|/det|>

<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 464, 144, 483]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 464, 777, 483]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 464, 920, 483]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 88]]<|/det|>

<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[175, 84, 819, 333]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 352, 920, 392]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the triangle \(OAC\). The point \(B\) is the midpoint of \(OC\). The point \(Y\) lies on \(AC\) such that \(OY\) intersects \(AB\) at the point \(X\) where \(AX:XB = 3:1\). It is given that \(\overrightarrow{OA} = \mathbf{a}\) and \(\overrightarrow{OB} = \mathbf{b}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 402, 144, 421]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 402, 702, 422]]<|/det|>
Find \(\overrightarrow{OX}\) in terms of \(\mathbf{a}\) and \(\mathbf{b}\), giving your answer in its simplest form.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 403, 920, 422]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 755, 146, 774]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 755, 386, 774]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 756, 920, 774]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 144, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 74, 589, 96]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\overrightarrow{OY} = h\overrightarrow{OX}\), find \(\overrightarrow{AY}\) in terms of \(\mathbf{a}\), \(\mathbf{b}\) and \(h\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 75, 918, 94]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 175, 146, 193]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 173, 566, 195]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\overrightarrow{AY} = \overrightarrow{mAC}\), find the value of \(h\) and of \(m\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 176, 920, 195]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 79, 104, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 79, 146, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 688, 104]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\frac{1}{x + 1} +\frac{2}{3x + 10}\) can be written as \(\frac{5x + 12}{3x^2 + 13x + 10}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 78, 920, 98]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 262, 146, 281]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 272, 875, 485]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 504, 923, 600]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows part of the curve \(y = \frac{5x + 12}{3x^2 + 13x + 10}\), the line \(x = 2\) and a straight line of gradient 1. The curve intersects the \(y\)-axis at the point \(P\). The line of gradient 1 passes through \(P\) and intersects the \(x\)-axis at the point \(Q\). Find the area of the shaded region, giving your answer in the form \(a + \frac{2}{3}\ln \bigl(b\sqrt{3}\bigr)\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 579, 920, 598]]<|/det|>
<mark>[9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[327, 71, 672, 89]]<|/det|>
Additional working space for question 10

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[333, 892, 665, 910]]<|/det|>
Question 11 is printed on the next page.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 106, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 146, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 75, 672, 94]]<|/det|>
Given that \(2\cos x = 3\tan x\) , show that \(2\sin^{2}x + 3\sin x - 2 = 0.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 75, 920, 94]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 395, 146, 413]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 395, 887, 432]]<|/det|>
Hence solve \(2\cos \left(2\alpha +\frac{\pi}{4}\right) = 3\tan \left(2\alpha +\frac{\pi}{4}\right)\) for \(0< \alpha < \pi\) radians, giving your answers in terms of \(\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 413, 920, 432]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]
